member.summary: Gets the URL for an icon for this device.
member.param: The MIME type of the encoding format that is requested for the icon.
Specifies the width of the icon, in pixels. Standard values are 16, 32, or 48.
Specifies the height of the icon, in pixels. Standard values are 16, 32, or 48 pixels.
Specifies the bit depth of the icon. Standard values are 8, 16, or 24.
member.returns: A string representing the URL for the icon.
member.remarks: An application can specify any values for lSizeX, lSizeY, and lBitDepth. However, there is no guarantee that an icon exists with those specifications. If a matching icon does not exist, the URL for the icon that most closely matches the size and bit depth specified is returned.

The requested height of the icon.
The requested bit depth of the icon.
member.returns: An image if found or null if not.

member.summary: Gets or sets the Search URI to filter devices by. A search uri can be a Device.Type, Device.UDN, or Service.ServiceTypeIdentifier in the form of urn:schemas-upnp-org:type:ver, uuid:00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000, or urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:type:ver. member.name: T:ManagedUPnP.Descriptions.OrderedIndexedDictionary`2
member.summary: Encapsulates a Dictionary which is guaranteed to preserve its order.
member.remarks:
According to the Microsoft doco, the Dictionary class will not necessarily preserve its order, this is because it stores its data in order of the hash key, not in the order added. However, I have tested this behaviour with Dictionaries of int, int. Using all different values in different orders, and the order always seems preserved. Either Microsoft is wrong, or the GetHashCode functions for int are really bad. Either way, this class is designed to keep the dictionary items in the same order they were added, which is necessary for the ArgumentsDescription dictionary.
This class takes up more memory, as it has to store a Dictionary and a List of keys, but it should be reasonably close in performance.
member.typeparam: The type for the keys in the dictionary.
The type for the values in the dictionary.
